Metadata: Isolation of non-01 "Vibrio cholerae" serovars from Oregon coastal environments

Water, sediment, and shellfish from three Oregon estuaries were cultured for pathogenic "Vibrio" species. Non-01 serovars of "V. cholerae" were the most common pathogenic "Vibrio" species, recovered from all three estuaries sampled, covering an area of about 170 miles along the Oregon coast. Non-01 "V. cholerae" were isolated from water and sediment at temperatures ranging from 11 to 19 deg C and salinities of 2.3 to 26 ppt; 16 isolates representing 12 different non-01 serovars were identified. Results indicate that non-01 "V. cholerae" serovars can be found over a large geographic area under a variety of environmental conditions; they are apparently an autochthonous component of these estuarine communities.
